abstract.p: Martin Guggenheim letter says case of Bently Louis Grant, the man wrongly arrested for assaulting Tiffany F Goldberg with a chunk of concrete, is a disturbing illustration of the ability of the police to create an 'overwhelming' case of guilt against an indisputably innocent person

block.p: Re ''Prosecutors Detail Evidence Leading to Suspect's Release: Videos Support Alibi for Concrete Attack'' (news article, July 27):

If not for the sheer happenstance that Bently Louis Grant was in range of the security cameras at the Virgin Megastore at the moment that Tiffany F. Goldberg was attacked, he would certainly have been prosecuted and most likely convicted on the basis of what everyone would call ''overwhelming'' evidence: two eyewitness identifications and a confession.

Why isn't there more public outrage over this case? Isn't anyone troubled by the apparent ability of the police to create an overwhelming case of guilt against an indisputably innocent person?
The writer is a professor at New York University Law School.
